Part A: Describe the role played by Africans such as Estevanico during the colonization of the Americas.

Examples that earn this point include but are not limited to the following:

  • Some worked as translators and intermediaries during the colonization of the Americas.

  • Some were explorers in territories that became the southwestern United States.

  • Some Africans served in the Spanish military forces in the conquest of new territories.

The response accomplishes the task set by part A of the question.

Part B: Explain how Atlantic Creoles were similar to or different from another group of Africans in the diaspora.

Examples that earn this point include but are not limited to the following:

  • While many of the Atlantic Creoles were already familiar with Iberian culture before they traveled to the Americas, a significant number of the Africans enslaved and sent to the Americas became familiar with European culture only after arriving in European colonies.

  • Some Atlantic Creoles, like the Africans that experienced the Middle Passage, were enslaved by Europeans.

  • Atlantic Creoles tended to have greater social mobility than the Africans that experienced chattel slavery in later periods.

  • Both Atlantic Creoles and the self-emancipated African Americans that lived at Fort Mose helped support the Spanish colony of Florida.

The response accomplishes the task set by part B of the question.

Part C: Explain how the work of African American Studies scholars has contributed to the understanding of developments such as those depicted in the source.

Examples that earn this point include but are not limited to the following:

  • African American Studies combines an interdisciplinary approach with the rigor of scholarly inquiry to develop an understanding of the history and contributions of people such as Estevanico.

  • African American Studies examines Africa’s relationship to communities of the African diaspora, including early communities with ladinos.

  • Interdisciplinary analysis in African American Studies dispels misconceptions of early Africa as a place with an unknowable history, instead revealing the significant role of Africans such as Estevanico in the colonization of the Americas.
